lines.text:
[Upset]
You were all I ever had. I don't love you anymore.
That was the chance I took.
[after Anna tells her about her ]
[Carrie's]
incestuous tendencies toward her brother] You never said those words. Tell me you never heard those words.

[to Julian and Anna]
We're together. The three of us. That's all that matters.
How is the shoe factory?
What shoe factory?
The shoe factory that you bought in Chicago.
Oh, that shoe factory. It's gone.
Don't be flip with me, Julian.
He's not. He's just trying to explain.
No, I'm not. I'm trying to explain anything. I was being flip. I forget. You worry about the money I lose.
I suppose rich people always worry about money. People like us have to learn there are more important things.
You can't go, Julian. Not now. You're - you're sick. Let us put you back on your feet just for a little while.
I'm on my feet now.
Oh, what are you gonna do? Go to her mother and live off her?
That wouldn't be much different from living off of you, would it?
You need us. How far have you ever gotten without us? How far do you think you're gonna get now?

I'll get as far as my wife and then as far as a hospital where there's a woman who needs my help a hell of a lot more than I need yours. After that, I don't know, but I can't go any lower, so it's bound to be up.

[to Julian tauntingly as he leaves the house]
Ha. Ha. Ha! Big, brave man. How long do you think that's going to last? Well, go on. Go on back to your crazy wife. You'll come crawling back here, you'll see. 'Cause you always have, you hear me? You've been a failure all your life. What makes you think it's going to change now? You hear me? You've been a failure. You have been a no account and a failure and you'll never be anything else. Julian! Julian! Julian!
[Breaks down and cries]
Oh, Julian, don't go, please, don't go. Julian!
God, what a mess I am.
You will be lonely.
That's all right. I always have been.

[Confused]
Where are you going?

[Referring to his wife, Lily]
To find her.
[to Anna]
Yes?

[Smiles]
Yes.
I'll be leaving now, big sister. You understand?
I understand.
You're crying.
I'm happy.

[Tipping the taxi driver extra]
Buy your baby something from me. And name the next one Julian.
Oh, my, he's gone. But he'll come back. Won't he? won't he?

[Leaving the house]
Goodbye, Carrie.
But he'll want you here when he comes back. He'll want us both the way it was.
[Anna walks away]
Ha! Ha! You'll be back too. You don't fool me.
[She goes back into the house]

And he'll be back too. I know he will be back. Because he always does comes back. Always. And when he does, we'll all just pretend that none of this ever happened. None of it. And then he'll take me in his arms and he'll say 'Carrie-pie, I'm sorry... I'm sorry."
[She cries and collapses on the staircase]
What are you doing?
Trying to understand.
Is it really...?
Yes, it really says we own this house.
This house - this awful, awful house! Doesn't he know that we always hated it? Just always, always, always, always.
You used to tell him how much we liked it.
Well, you know that was only to keep him from being ashamed of the house and what we didn't have.
Well... we've been rewarded.
Anna, for God's sake, take off that hat!
Oh, Julian, be careful. He'd do anything to get back at you if he knew.
Don't you worry about me. He only beats up women.
Now, look, honey, you go back upstairs, finish packing, and don't forget my toothbrush like you did in Chicago, okay?
And another Berniers homecoming. Only today it's the real thing. Yesterday was out of a storybook.
Hey, now, look what you're doing just when I was trying to get my big-money look. Hey, do you like my new tie? $8.50, not including tax.
Is that you, Carrie?
Yes, I just got home. Oh, it's hot.
Did you have a hard day?
Well, he let me leave the office right after lunch. He said, "You're looking a little peaked, Miss Berniers, from the heat." Well, I said, "I have been looking a little...
[sighs]
... peaked from the heat for years. You just mean you're hot and you want to go home, you old faker." I said - only I said it to myself.
We had a private sale at the store - winter coats on a day like this.
So, anyway, I left early, and I took some flowers to the cemetery.
Everybody still there?

Oh, nobody goes to see anybody in the summer. Yet those we have passed away must be just as lonely in the summer as they are in the winter. Sometimes, I think we shouldn't have put mama and papa out at Mount Olive Cemetery, maybe it would have been nicer for them out at Mount Great Hope with the new rich people. What do you think if we don't get buried at Mount Olive with mama and papa?
Any place that's cool.
Ya'll sure need a new icebox. You ought to treat yourselves. No more Julian to worry about.

I am gonna tell you something, Gus! We *are* gonna treat ourselves. We have just got a wonderful offer on the house, and we're gonna sell it. And we're gonna take a long trip to Europe for a year of five. What do you think about that?
You told me that last year, and I stopped the ice. You told me that two years ago when Julian went on one of his other business trips, and I stopped the ice then.
[Chuckles]
When do I stop it now?
Soon - very soon, you hear me? And if you just don't believe me, then you come around to church on Sunday and hear us take a solemn oath right in church. We don't break a solemn oath right in church.
Well, that's good. Lots of people do.

Do you remember when Julian told us about the marriage? And he said, "Soon, we'll all go to Europe together." Well, you know... if you and I can't go to Europe, we could afford a little trip to Chicago. The coach fares are very cheap.
Julian? Julian?
Expecting somebody else?
[first lines]
Mr. Berniers?
Hi.
Mr. Berniers. Mr. Berniers. Now, I hate to bother you, but it's been quite some time now.
Oh, relax. Just make up the bill. Make it up in full, you hear? I'll be checking out later today.
Julian, let the police help.
What for? They'd only laugh at me. Julian Berniers with a $150,000 in his pocket - you think they'd swallow that?
Don't you know what's the matter? Don't you know? You want to sleep with him. You always have. Years ago, I used to be frightened that you would try and I would watch you and suffer for you.
